Message.Msg: Bank of America Corp (NYSE:BAC): Julius Baer Group Ltd., the Swiss money manager established in 1890, is near an agreement for the acquisition of Bank of America Corp.â€™s Merrill Lynch wealth management businesses outside the U.S., according to two people familiar with the matter. An announcement could come as soon as Aug. 13, according the people, who asked not to be identified because the situation is private. Julius Baer stated on June 19 that it was in talks to buy the Merrill Lynch units, which could be valued at $1.5 billion to $2 billion, the people claimed. Message.Title: 2013 could be the start of $20+
Message.Msg: BAC needs to get a settlement with Fannie/freddie resolved before yr end. They should settle15 billion in claims with about 3-5 billion at most. Once completed the balance sheet will look real good when combined with the amount of teired assets they have accumulated over the last 2 yrs. Then in 2013 when the Fed does their stress test BAC should be able to do a buyback &/or a stock dividend. I would prefer a buyback first of about 3 billion. Once fed approved BAC will jump to the $15/sh level easily. IMO this is the time to accumulate shares as we are easily within 9 months of a double. Fed normally releases their stress test findings in March and BAC should be approved to do buyback or dividend by then.

Message.Title: Fair share???
Message.Msg: " It so happens that this summer the Internal Revenue Service released data from the 400 individual income tax returns reporting the highest adjusted gross income. This elite ultrarich group earned on average $202 million in 2009, the latest year available. And buried in the data is the startling disclosure that six of the 400 paid no federal income tax. The I.R.S. has never before disclosed that last fact. Not even Mr. Romney, with reported 2010 income of $21.7 million, qualifies for membership in this select group of 400. But the data provides a window into the financial lives and tax rates of the superrich. Since the I.R.S. doesnâ€™t release data for the tiny percentage of Americans at Mr. Romneyâ€™s income level, the 400 are the closest proxy. And that data demonstrates that many of the ultrarich can and do reduce their tax liability to very low levels, even zero. Besides the six who paid no federal income tax, the I.R.S. reported that 27 paid from zero to 10 percent of their adjusted gross incomes and another 89 paid between 10 and 15 percent, which is close to the 13.9 percent rate that Mr. Romney disclosed that he paid in 2010. (At the other end of the spectrum, 82 paid 30 to 35 percent. None paid more than 35 percent.) So more than a quarter of the people earning an average of over $200 million in 2009 paid less than 15 percent of their adjusted gross income in taxes. "

Topic.Title: The only place democraps want to drill is our wallets

Message.Msg: Post-Katrina, oil speculators drove crude oil to more than $145 per barrel, and domestic refinery and distribution disruptions let gas speculators drive pump prices to around $3.60 per gallon. Now, with crude at $94 per barrel, gas prices are crowding $4.00 a gallon; meanwhile, refined petroleum EXPORTS have reached record levels; the Gulf Coast refineries are selling your gas on foreign markets! Oops, by talking math, I've taken the conversation where neo-cons can't follow it. ROTFLMAO at Ouja Board and divining rod believers everywhere.

Topic.Title: OCTOBER 10 CALLS

Message.Msg: 200 bucks is 200 bucks. I am not a fan of out of the money calls almost 30% up. It's like taking 200 bucks out of your pocket and lighting a match to it. I'd rather hold 200 dollars worth of shares and IF it goes up 30%, you have 60 bucks. If not, you'll most likely be up anyway. There is no way to consistently build a portfolio based on options. You'll be jerking your account back and forth, mostly back.
